name: miro_value_selling
description: A conversation framework (inspired by Command of the Message) that uncovers customer needs and connects them to Miro's differentiated value using Positive Business Outcomes, Required Capabilities, and Measurable Business Outcomes.
valueDrivers: Go to market faster with better quality

components.name: Before Scenario
components.description: Understand the customer's current state: how they work today, tools, workflows, and baseline performance.

subComponents.name: Current State Discovery
subComponents.description: Understanding of current workflows, tools, and stakeholders
exampleQuestions: Walk me through how your teams collaborate today from strategy to delivery.
Which tools are in play for workshops, planning, and execution? Where do handoffs break?
What's working well, and where do things slow down or cause friction?
How often do you need live meetings to stay aligned? What's the impact?
Who are the key stakeholders involved across functions and geos?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear, specific description of current workflows, tools, and stakeholders; customer validates accuracy.
scoringCriteria.good: Solid overview with several specifics; minor gaps remain.
scoringCriteria.fair: Basic outline of current state; limited detail or validation.
scoringCriteria.poor: Vague or assumed current state; little customer input.

coachingTips: Map the flow end-to-end (where work starts, travels, and finishes).
Capture the systems of record and collaboration tools, not just meeting habits.
Confirm your understanding back to the customer.

components.name: Negative Consequences
components.description: Surface the business impact of the status quo: delays, costs, risk, and experience issues.

subComponents.name: Business Impact Analysis
subComponents.description: Quantification of problems and their business impact
exampleQuestions: What happens to the business when alignment breaks down or meetings are missed?
Where do context switching and tool sprawl create waste or confusion?
Have security, compliance, or shadow IT risks shown up?
How do current ways of working affect employee morale or burnout?
If nothing changes this quarter, what's the consequence?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Specific, quantified impacts (time, cost, risk, engagement) tied to business objectives; multiple stakeholder perspectives captured.
scoringCriteria.good: Clear problems and some quantification or concrete examples.
scoringCriteria.fair: Problems identified but loosely tied to business impact.
scoringCriteria.poor: Generic pains with no business relevance.

coachingTips: Ask 'What breaks and who feels it?' for depth.
Probe for real examples (last incident, frequency, scale).
Connect impacts to leadership objectives.

components.name: After Scenario
components.description: Envision the desired future state once problems are addressed.

subComponents.name: Future State Vision
subComponents.description: Clear articulation of the desired target state
exampleQuestions: Assuming these challenges were solved, how would work look different?
Which meetings could become async or shorter - and what would that unlock?
How would distributed teams coordinate in your ideal flow?
What would leadership see in a unified view of work?
What would change first, and who benefits most?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Crisp, practical future state aligned to strategic priorities; stakeholders agree it's desirable and realistic.
scoringCriteria.good: Compelling vision with partial alignment or detail.
scoringCriteria.fair: High-level aspirations without clear operational changes.

coachingTips: Anchor the vision to specific workflows (e.g., planning → delivery).
Contrast the 'after' with today to crystallize value.
Sequence early wins before long-term changes.

components.name: Positive Business Outcomes
components.description: Define the Measurable Business Outcomes (MBOs) the customer wants (e.g., faster velocity, decreased spend, higher engagement).

subComponents.name: Outcome Definition & Prioritization
exampleQuestions: Which business outcomes matter most here (e.g., time to market, fewer meetings, lower travel, higher adoption)?
If we accelerate time-to-market by X, what does that change for revenue or competitiveness?
How would you describe success to your exec sponsor in one sentence?
Which outcomes are non-negotiable this quarter vs. nice-to-have?
How will these outcomes support your broader initiatives (e.g., product strategy, transformation, talent)?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear, prioritized outcomes with success thresholds; expressed in measurable terms the customer will track.
scoringCriteria.good: Relevant outcomes with general measurability and prioritization.
scoringCriteria.fair: Outcomes listed but loosely defined or unprioritized.
scoringCriteria.poor: Vague benefits with no linkage to measurement.

coachingTips: Use customer language (velocity, releases, adoption, eNPS).
Prioritize 2-3 outcomes; avoid laundry lists.
Tie outcomes explicitly to exec-level objectives.

components.name: Required Capabilities
components.description: Identify the minimum capabilities needed to realize the Positive Business Outcomes.

subComponents.name: Capability Mapping
subComponents.description: Minimum required capabilities mapped to targeted outcomes
exampleQuestions: What capabilities must be in place to achieve those outcomes (e.g., unified workspace, async workshops, deep Jira/ADO integrations)?
What does 'enterprise-grade security and governance' specifically mean for you?
Which integrations are essential on day one vs. phase two?
What do you need for hybrid meetings to be as effective as in-person?
What admin and reporting controls would make this sustainable at scale?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Minimum required capabilities are explicit, testable, and mapped one-to-one to targeted outcomes; customer validates sufficiency.
scoringCriteria.good: Clear capability list with partial mapping to outcomes.
scoringCriteria.fair: Capabilities generally defined without strong mapping or testability.
scoringCriteria.poor: Capabilities vague or feature-dumped; unclear relevance.

coachingTips: Translate outcomes → capabilities; avoid unrelated features.
Probe for scale, security, and integration depth early.
Document 'phase 1 vs. later' capability expectations.

components.name: Metrics
components.description: Agree how outcomes and capabilities will be measured (Measurable Business Outcomes).

subComponents.name: Measurement Framework
subComponents.description: Specific metrics with baselines, targets, and ownership
exampleQuestions: How will you measure success (leading and lagging indicators)?
What baselines do you have today for time-to-market, meeting hours, travel, or adoption?
What cadence and who owns reporting on these metrics?
Which metrics signal early wins in the first 30-60 days?
What thresholds define 'good enough' vs. 'must improve'?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Specific leading/lagging metrics with baselines, targets, owners, and review cadence.
scoringCriteria.good: Clear metrics with some baseline/owner details.
scoringCriteria.fair: General metrics with limited specificity or accountability.

coachingTips: Capture baselines during discovery; don't wait for deployment.
Align metrics to exec dashboards the customer already uses.
Include adoption and enablement metrics, not only business KPIs.

components.name: Proof Points
components.description: Provide evidence (customers, benchmarks, analyst quotes) that Miro can deliver the outcomes with the required capabilities.

subComponents.name: Credibility & Evidence
subComponents.description: Relevant proof points tied to customer's outcomes and capabilities
exampleQuestions: Would examples from peers in your industry be helpful?
Which outcomes would you like us to evidence (e.g., fewer meetings, reduced travel, faster releases, higher eNPS)?
Do you want to speak with a customer who consolidated point tools or scaled hybrid workshops?
What kind of third-party validation resonates most for your execs?
Which security/compliance proof points do you need to see?

scoringCriteria.excellent: Credible, relevant proof tied to the customer's outcomes and capabilities; customer acknowledges fit.
scoringCriteria.good: Relevant proof points shared; partial tie to outcomes.

coachingTips: Match proof points to the customer's industry and outcomes.
Show capability depth (integrations, scale, security) with specifics.
Offer direct customer connects when appropriate.

notes: Emphasis on Positive Business Outcomes and Required Capabilities (50% total).
Use 'Measurable Business Outcomes' terminology; avoid ROI modeling unless the customer requests it.
Discovery questions are examples; adapt by persona and value driver.
